Award.AwardTitle: Undergraduate Curriculum Guide for the Mathematical Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through MAA's Committee on the Undergraduate Program in Mathematics (CUPM), the MAA has released a Curriculum Guide approximately once every decade. The last such Guide was released in 2004. CUPM is now developing the next generation of guidelines and recommendations to help mathematical sciences departments effectively meet the challenges they face in educating the next generation of STEM leaders. Students interested in STEM careers have many more choices than they did twenty years ago. The array of possibilities in course offerings, standards, and requirements has left many mathematics departments asking for assistance in designing and innovating mathematical sciences majors for the 21st century.

To develop the next Guide, CUPM has formed groups of faculty from diverse institutions to focus on specific courses and program areas. Focus groups have been convened at national meetings to help shape CUPM's efforts. Panel discussions at national meetings are being used to solicit further input. Draft guidelines will be circulated broadly in advance of the formal release, targeted for early 2015, in order to ensure that the Guide meets the needs of the mathematical sciences, and broader STEM, communities. In addition, MAA will organize sessions at national and regional meetings, both during the development of the Guide and after its release, to provide guidance to faculty and departments for using the recommendations to improve their undergraduate mathematics program. NSF's Division of Mathematical Sciences is providing co-funding, reflecting its interest in improving undergraduate education in the mathematical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mathematical Association of America (MAA) Committee on the Undergraduate Program in Mathematics (CUPM) is charged with making recommendations to guide mathematics departments in designing curricula for their undergraduate students. Historically, this committee updates these recommendations and policy statements at roughly 10-year intervals. For the 2012-2015 effort, CUPM held panel discussions, met with focus groups, and solicited position papers from prominent mathematicians and stakeholder representatives. The project steering committee chose three areas of approach: (#1) Course Study Groups prepared documents that discussed the variety of acceptable undergraduate courses in various areas of mathematical sciences, at different levels or aimed at different students; (#2) Program Study Groups generated advice on starting interdisciplinary programs; and (#3) the steering committee and invited experts prepared a document focused on the essentials of any mathematical sciences major and sent print copies to all department chairs in the U.S.

The intellectual merit of the project is primarily reflected through the in-depth and far-reaching attention paid to the various constituent groups involved in the three-year production of the 2015 CUPM Guide. At the time CUPM was preparing this material the American Statistical Association and the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics were preparing their own respective guidelines for undergraduate programs in statistics and applied mathematics, and their recommendations have been included in the 2015 CUPM Guide.  Similarly, the section on Actuarial Science depends heavily on the American Actuarial Society recommendations, and MAA’s Committee on the Mathematical Education of Teachers contributed several updates to the section on teacher education in accordance with guidelines from the appropriate professional associations. Finally, CUPM's subcommittee on Curriculum Renewal Across the First Two Years conducted workshops with participants from a broad range of partner disciplines, resulting in position papers on what these disciplines want their students to learn in the mathematics classes that they take. CUPM’s subcommittee on Mathematics Across the Disciplines contributed a course study on Mathematical Models, but also was instrumental in helping to prepare the reports on Programs.  

The most significant of the project’s broader impacts comes from the wide dissemination of finished materials. In addition to the print document (described as #3 above) sent to all department chairs in the U.S., the entire document is also available online at maa.org/cupm. The guide also has undergone substantial vetting from the professional societies. The MAA’s Board of Governors reaffirmed the basic principles in the 2004 Guide, which are included among the recommendations in the 2015 guide.  The Board of Governors also approved the four Cognitive and nine Content Recommendations presented in the Overview of Majors in the Mathematical Sciences as essential to any undergraduate program leading to a degree in the mathematical sciences. Also important for broader impact is the emphasis on a department’s continual evaluation and action to improve. The project finished with focused conversations about facilitating institutional change, both within the sphere of curriculum reform and more broadly.  There is certainly more work to be done.
